qas.question: What plant was used to make the most used red dye in Venice?
Which group in Europe used Kermes dye?
The wealthiest in Europe used what red dye?
What dye was known as the Blood of Saint John?
The Blood of Saint John was made from an insect, which one?
What was the Venice plant used to make?

plausible_answers.text: made by collecting and crushing Porphyophora hamelii

qas.question: How was the finest red of Kermes vermilio made?
What city was rubia used to make dyes for the wealthy?
What insect was found in Persia?

context: There were guilds of dyers who specialized in red in <b7_0>Venice<b7_0/> and other large Europeans cities. The <a0_0>Rubia<a0_0/> plant was used to make <b5_0>the most common dye<b5_0/>; it produced an orange-red or brick red color used to dye the clothes of merchants and artisans. For <a1_0>the wealthy<a1_0/>, the dye used was Kermes, made from a tiny scale insect which fed on the branches and leaves of the oak tree. For those with even more money there was <a2_0>Polish Cochineal<a2_0/>; also known as <a3_0>Kermes vermilio<a3_0/> or "Blood of Saint John", which was made from a related insect, the <a4_0>Margodes polonicus<a4_0/>. It made a more vivid red than ordinary Kermes. The finest and most expensive variety of red made from insects was the "Kermes" of Armenia (Armenian cochineal, also known as Persian kirmiz), <b6_0>made by collecting and crushing <b8_0>Porphyophora hamelii<b8_0/><b6_0/>, an insect which lived on the roots and stems of certain grasses. The pigment and dye merchants of Venice imported and sold all of these products and also manufactured their own color, called Venetian red, which was considered the most expensive and finest red in Europe. Its secret ingredient was arsenic, which brightened the color.
